channel.title: NER Washington Forum
channel.description:
Discussion series featuring a prominent figure affecting federal government policy.

An online collection of early educational public radio content from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters (NAEB).

item.title: American Dairy Farmers bill
item.description: Representative B.F. Sisk discusses the American Dairy Farmers Bill and aid to farmers.
item.dc:creator: Greenwood, Bill
item.dc:subject: United States--Politics and government

item.title: White House Fellows program
item.description: Thomas Carr, director of President's Commission on White House Fellows.
item.dc:creator: Greenwood, Bill
item.dc:subject: United States--Politics and government

item.title: Police riot control training, part 2
item.description: This program, the second of two parts, focuses on police riot control training at Fairfax County, Virginia, near Washington, D.C.
item.dc:creator: Greenwood, Bill
item.dc:subject: United States--Politics and government

item.title: Teacher Corps
item.description: Richard Graham, director, National Teacher Corps, on educating poverty-stricken children.
item.dc:creator: Sussman, Vic S.
item.dc:subject: United States--Politics and government

item.title: Presidency and the Press
item.description: The Presidency and the Press. Guest: George Christian, press secretary to President Johnson and successor to Bill Moyers.
item.dc:creator: Greenwood, Bill
item.dc:subject: United States--Politics and government

item.title: Race relations in the United States
item.description: The guest for this program is Dr. Nathan Hare, African-American sociologist.

item.dc:subject: United States--Politics and government

item.title: Challenge to the Warren Commission
item.description: A Challenge to the Warren Commission, part 2. New Orleans District Attorney Jim Garrison charges the U.S. government with concealing the truth about the assassination of President John F. Kennedy
item.dc:creator: Sussman, Vic S.
item.dc:subject: United States--Politics and government

item.title: Congressional Quarterly editors
item.description: Editors from Congressional Quarterly assess the 90th Congress of the United States.
item.dc:creator: Sussman, Vic S.
item.dc:subject: United States--Politics and government

item.title: Public Broadcasting Act of 1967
item.description: House hearings on Public Broadcasting Act of 1967. Includes: United States Representative Claude Pepper (D-Florida); Thomas Hoving; Frank Stanton; McGeorge Bundy; Fred Friendly; and Jerrold Sandler.
item.dc:creator: Greenwood, Bill
item.dc:subject: United States--Politics and government

item.title: Public Broadcasting Act of 1967, part five
item.description: Senate hearings on Public Broadcasting Act of 1967. Highlighted testimony of Dr. Frank Stanton, president of CBS, announcing $1 million gift to newly-chartered Corporation for Public Broadcasting.
item.dc:creator: Greenwood, Bill
item.dc:subject: United States--Politics and government

item.title: Columnist Robert Novak
item.description: Columnist Robert Novak, about President Lyndon Johnson's decline in popularity.
item.dc:creator: Greenwood, Bill
item.dc:subject: United States--Politics and government

item.title: Filmmaker Felix Greene
item.description: British filmmaker Felix Greene discusses the film Inside North Vietnam, and American foreign policy in Southeast Asia.
item.dc:creator: Sussman, Vic S.
item.dc:subject: United States--Politics and government

item.title: Abortion, part 2
item.description: Report on international conference on abortion, held in Washington, D.C. Guests are: Dr. Carl Kaysen, director, Institute for Advanced Studies, Princeton, NJ.; and Dr. Andre Hellegers, Georgetown University School of Medicine.
item.dc:creator: Greenwood, Bill
item.dc:subject: United States--Politics and government

item.title: Public Broadcasting Act of 1967, part six
item.description: Discussion of Public Broadcasting Act of 1967 and a Ford Foundation report, "The Hidden Medium." Guests: Jerrold Sandler, executive director, National Educational Radio Network, and Herman W. Land, consultant.
item.dc:creator: Greenwood, Bill
item.dc:subject: United States--Politics and government

item.title: A U.S. Constitutional Convention?, part 2
item.description: Proposed United States Constitutional Convention. Guest: United States Senator Joseph Tydings, D-Maryland.
item.dc:creator: Greenwood, Bill
item.dc:subject: United States--Politics and government

item.title: Urban problems
item.description: Irving Hand, president, American Institute of Planners and executive director, Pennsylvania State Planning Board, on urban problems in America.

item.dc:subject: United States--Politics and government

item.title: Election campaign reform, part 2
item.description: This program focuses on election campaign reform. United States Senator James B. Pearson, R-Kansas.

item.dc:subject: United States--Politics and government

item.title: Public Broadcasting Act of 1967, part one
item.description: This program, the first of six, explores the Senate Hearings on Public Broadcasting Act of 1967. Highlighted testimony before the U.S. Senate Commerce Subcommittee on Communications, chaired by Senator John Pastore.
item.dc:creator: Greenwood, Bill
item.dc:subject: United States--Politics and government

item.title: Muhammad Ali
item.description: Muhammad Ali discusses the draft, race relations, and the Muslim religion.

item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Veterans' home mortgage fraud
item.description: Home mortgage fraud affecting military veterans. Guests are United States Representative Charles E. Bennett (D-Florida); and Harry D. Dodson of the Veterans Administration.

item.dc:subject: United States--Politics and government

item.title: Election campaign reform, part 1
item.description: This program focuses on election campaign reform. Guests are United States Senator Robert F. Kennedy, D-New York; United States Senator Everett Dirksen, R-Illinois.

item.title: Abortion, part 1
item.description: Report on international conference on abortion, held in Washington, D.C. Guests are: Eunice Kennedy Shriver, Executive Vice President, Joseph P. Kennedy, Jr., Foundation, and Dean Bayliss Manning, Stanford University School of Law.

item.title: Rev. William Sloane Coffin and Ossie Davis
item.description: Reverend William Sloane Coffin, Yale University chaplain who had been indicted for counseling young men to resist the draft; and actor Ossie Davis. Both discuss antiwar mobilization in Washington, D.C.
item.dc:creator: Sussman, Vic S.
item.dc:subject: United States--Politics and government

item.description: United Nations Ambassador Arthur Goldberg, speaking at National Press Club on Vietnam, the Paris peace talks, the Middle East.

item.title: Problems facing American Indians
item.description: This program focuses on problems facing Native Americans and the government efforts to solve those problems. Guest: Robert L. Bennett, United States Commissioner of Indian Affairs.

item.title: Vice President Hubert Humphrey
item.description: Vice President Hubert Humphrey, speaking about the President's Council on Youth Opportunity. He refers to hippies and the youth movement.

item.title: Dr. Werner Von Braun
item.description: 10th anniversary of United States space exploration. On Jan. 31, 1958, Explorer I was launched. Developers included Dr. Werner Von Braun and Dr. William Pickering, who speak to National Press Club in this recording.

item.title: Antiwar protestor Gary Rader
item.description: Former Army Special Forces member Gary Rader, a former Green Beret, discusses his antiwar activism. Part 2 of 4: War in Vietnam.

item.title: New role of freshmen Congressmen
item.description: The New Role of Freshmen Congressmen, in the 90th Congress. Guests: United States Representative Howard W. Pollock, R-Alaska; United States Representative Jerry L. Pettis, R-California.

item.description: Discussion on state of national economy and status of President Lyndon Johnson's proposed tax surcharge bill. The guest for this program is Gardner Ackley, chairman, President's Council of Economic Advisors.
